Skyward is down. This message will go out to families tomorrow:

Over the past several days, we have conducted a number of feedback sessions with our families and staff highlighting our plans for returning to school. We have heard feedback from parents regarding the difficulty of making a full-year commitment to the Huron Valley Virtual Academy. Therefore, we have made the decision to change our requirement to a semester commitment. We believe this better addresses families' needs and takes into account the possibility that Michigan may be in a different phase of the Governor's MI Safe Start Plan.

Please visit the HVVA webpage for more information regarding enrollment. Continue to monitor the webpage and posted Frequently Asked Questions for updates.

In addition, we want to make you aware that while we currently have two learning options for families -- face to face and virtual -- we continue to explore additional models being implemented by school districts across Michigan.

Although the Milford Memorial Day Parade was cancelled this year, the HVS band programs were committed to remembering the day’s true meaning.

With a brief ceremony put together with Mr. Joe Salvia of the Huron Valley AMVETS and the Milford American Legion, our buglers – Lakeland's Kira Kildal and Milford's Molly Weisberg – were at Central Park to play the traditional Taps ceremonies. The park was quiet, but the purpose was the same. Students and staff practiced social distancing and were respectful of the number of people gathered at Central Park.

Earlier in the day, Molly played taps at local cemeteries and Kira performed at American House. It was great to see these two outstanding students and citizens represent our band programs with pride, honoring those who made the ultimate sacrifice. #HVSProud #MemorialDay

We are all so #HVSProud of our educators, who are working creatively to keep students engaged during the COVID-19 shutdown. We'd like to highlight these efforts, beginning with Mr. Seth Stern at Spring Mills Elementary. Keep watching for many more to come.

Mr. Stern has created engaging activities for his fourth-grade class -- aka Stern’s Super Stars -- as home learning continues. His goal, he explained, was to make virtual learning accessible to students and easy for parents/guardians.

Many activities are project based: using measurement to bake, researching a region of the U.S., writing letters and doing interactive projects and science experiments. He’s also encouraged students to use online platforms like Moby Max, Readworks, Think Central and Kahn Academy.

Mr. Stern created a private Facebook group for his class, so parents and students can stay connected and draw inspiration for learning from one another.

Last year, HVS initiated a partnership with SafeStop, a school bus tracking app designed to allow parents to know when their children would be picked up and dropped off by the bus. At the beginning of the 2019-2020 school year, HVS along with other Michigan districts experienced significant technical difficulties in getting SafeStop to function properly on our buses. Those issues continue and do not appear to have a positive resolution.

Therefore, HVS is exploring alternative technologies that will coordinate with our current GPS system. Within the next month, we will be rolling out a new bus tracking application that we believe will be more reliable in providing real-time information to HVS families.

We apologize for any inconvenience these technical difficulties have caused. The safety of HVS students is paramount. We are committed to providing a solution that meets the needs of our families.

Kurtz Elementary celebrated two great beginnings last week. The beginning of the new school year and the 50th anniversary of the opening of Kurtz were both remarkable. At the 50th birthday celebration, guests included former students of all ages, past and present staff members and even future students.

A group of Kurtz fifth-graders provided a guided tour of the building, pointing out features and facts that make their school unique. Guests couldn’t help but admire and appreciate the work of these Kurtz student leaders. Visitors also “Made Their Mark” with acrylic paint on canvas, representing those who have made their mark on Kurtz over the past 50 years. The murals will hang in the hallways to remind us of those who came before us, those who are a part of our family now and even some that will join the Kurtz family in the future. Happy birthday, Kurtz!
